issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
Sometimes, a fragment can run for a long time after a query fails. It looks from logs like the abort/interrupt were called correctly on the thread, yet the thread hangs around minutes after, doing the below. Other tasks for the same job appear to have exited correctly, after the same abort logic (at least, the same log lines, fwiw)

comments.body:
This patch contains 2 changes.
1) Adds interrupt checking every N batches to the bottom-level vectorized map join cc [~mmccline]

2) Makes the abort check in RecordProcessor self-adjust towards a time-based target (the main goal is to make it reduce the row interval for slow pipelines, esp. w/VRBs). Calling time functions every row seems like it would be too expensive.  cc [~sseth] [~rajesh.balamohan] [~gopalv]

Here are the results of testing the latest attachment:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12855441/HIVE-16078.patch

{color:red}ERROR:{color} -1 due to no test(s) being added or modified.

ATTACHMENT ID: 12855441 - PreCommit-HIVE-Build

Adjusting the interval makes sense to me. I'm not sure about the cost impact though. Think the maybeCheckAbort method needs some tests though.
- Cast to double in the division
- The new adjusted value for nRows may be reversed - i.e. increased if things took to long, and reduced if the check happened faster.

Will let [~mmccline] comment on the other changes.

Do you know of any other operators which can end up spending a lot of time on a single row? (How would outer joins factor into this for example?)

[~sseth] will test in the cluster eventually; the constant is already double; not sure how nRows can be reversed - can you elaborate? the limit is only changed when nRows is set to 0. As for long ops, not sure. In this case each item is a VRB, not row, so assuming no interrupt checks in the pipeline 1000-"row" interval translates into ~1M actual rows processed between check. I also suspect based on the method names (forwardOverflow etc.) that some batching may be happening internally, making it even more rows. Perhaps [~mmccline] can comment given the callstack above
Actually also the division is reversed. Should be target / actual, then multiply by current rows. So it the actual time was half of target, we double the row-based interval.
I also feel the target time could be bigger, maybe 1-5 seconds or so.

I haven't looked at the patch yet, but forwardOverflow kicks in when a big table key matches > 1 small table key.  When there is just 1 small table key and value, then we put the small table value in the input VRB and forward it.  When > 1, then you can get output explosion, of course.  The big table key is copied into the overflow batch and then multiple small table values are copied in generating more rows.

So, native Vector MapJoin forward either a Big Table (the input batch) VRBs with only matched rows selected, or overflow output VRBs when they fill up.

bq. Actually also the division is reversed. Should be target / actual, then multiply by current rows. So it the actual time was half of target, we double the row-based interval.
That's what I meant by reversed. A time miss would lead to increasing the number of rows.
Didn't realize the parameter was already a double.

[~rajesh.balamohan] I added the constant, but if the check ends up being too fast in terms of time it will presumably self-adjust back up after one (or few) checks. So for now I set the constant to 1. Will look at merge join.

Updated the patch. Moved to a separate class to use in the pushRecord loop in merge join.
[~sseth] can you especially take a look at the logic in ReduceRecordProcessor::close? it looks like it closes sources only if the thing is aborted, and only until one of the sources returns false, which also un-aborts the processor (the abort flag is unset).
I preserved this Chesterton's fence but it seems a little strange.

[~mmccline] can you still look at the vectorized join part?
VectorMapJoinGenerateResultOperator code looks ok, except what about adding the maybeCheckInterrupt check call forwardBigTableBatch path, also?
